body: Please post the code for opening the form and for submit button.

@Thoulah Yeah, I'm using `Html::submitInput` on another form and it doesn't make any difference; but generally I prefer to use `button`'s - the `Html::submitInput` is probably a remnant from earlier code.
@cyphix333, is your objective to prevent multiple submissions?
@dynasource yes. He's disabling the button after 1st submit.

Ive thought about this one a while. In the past Ive been using events like this. Adding 'disabled' as attribute + adding CSS, but although it looks like its working, you can be misleaded. 

Different events for the submission of forms can override your events which makes your double submission prevention useless.

A trick which works 100% of the time though, without being 'disturbed' by other events, is the use of a ghost button. When you submit, a hidden 'brother' button is shown/created without functionality. You can click what you want on this brother, but it can never lead to a submission or trigger a submission event. Based on your configuration, you can show this brother for a few seconds.
@dynasource Hmmmmm...... interesting technique; and yes, I can see it's merit. That's something I am definitely going to be looking at moving forward. :)
Ill open a new topic for this

@samdark Looks cool. Gonna have to give that a shot too, though I generally don't re-enable the submit button unless it's an ajax form (which I do via jQuerys _always_ promise method) as there isn't much point as it will be enabled again on the next page if there was an error.
Solution is by @SilverFire. I haven't tested it myself...
